page.title: 18ARCHAEOLOGY IN ESKDALEMUIR
page.content: Eskdalemuir is rich in local history having been occupied at one time by the Romans,and ,earlier still,the Ancient Briton. Excavations carried out prove that what was originally believed to be a hill fort was infact a crematorium or a place for athletic sports and to have been built by the the Ancient Britons. The oldest archealogical remains in Eskdalemuir are the girdle stones, erected by the Ancient Britons in 1290 BC.A smaller circle of stones of which only two are still standing are called the "Louping stones"the old tradition being that the lads used to jump from one to the other - a distance of 8ft. Most probebly they were open temples of the Early Britons. Eskdalemuir is traversed by several traceable Roman roads or "ways" there are many hill forts and a Roman camp.
